chapter.title: The &BRAMPUINO1X;
chapter.para:
The &BRAMPUINO1X; is a small device based on the open Arduino hardware platform to make series of frames automatically. In its simpliest setting it acts as a normal intervalometer (this is the default setting).
It can be configured to be used as an HDRI intervalometer as well.
Additionally it can be used as a Bulb Ramper like the &LITTLE_BRAMPER;.
The &BRAMPUINO1X; is one of the few devices that can ramp the exposure time via the camera's bulb mode and the ISO automatically!

warning.title: Canon Cameras only
warning.para: At the current state of development only Canon cameras are supported.

chapter.para: We give a short introduction to the required pieces of hardware to build &BRAMPUINO1X; in . These are all off-the-shelf components.
In we list the open-source software that is needed if the source code will be altered and re-compiled.

section.title: Hardware
section.para:
The following hardware is required:
Arduino Uno Rev3
The Arduino Uno Rev3 is the basic platform for this prototype.
USB Host Shield by Circuits@Home
The USB Host Shield is used to talk to the Canon Camera via USB.
The makers of this shield provide the software libraries too.
RGB LCD Shield
The RGB LCD Shield by Adafruit with its 5 buttons is the interface between &BRAMPUINO1X; and the photographer.
This shield was used because it uses the I2C-bus and uses less pins than other shields. These remaining pins can be used to interact with other devices.

chapter.title: Interface
chapter.para: The &BRAMPUINO1X; provides a simple text based interface via the 16x2 RGB LCD shield and 5 buttons to set parameters and start &BRAMPUINO1X;.

In we give the structure of the menu hierarchy with a short explanation of each menu item and in we show how to navigate with the buttons through the menu.
The display is shown in .

tip.title: Exposure Offset
tip.para: If you use LiveView with a &CANON5DMKII; then you should set the exposure offset to a value around 200. The camera needs this time to reset the mirror/shutter.

tip.title: Minimal Interval
tip.para: If you use LiveView with a &CANON5DMKII; then you should set the minimal interval to a value around 2000. The camera needs this time for an unknown reason.

tip.title: ISO Change
tip.para: ISO values are changed on the camera only, if ISO ramping is activated.

tip.title: Move Focus
tip.para: The move focus option does not work reliably with a &CANON5DMKII;. If it works with your camera then report the camera model, the lens and the setting to us, please.

tip.title: Lead In
tip.para: The first frame after the lead in has still the start exposure time.

section.title: Display
section.para:
When &MENU_start; in the menu is selected then &BRAMPUINO1X; stores the current setting in the EEPROM, if the values have changed from the previous setting.
Then it switches the RGB LCD Screen color to red which looks like this:
3/5 ISO50 B:1057/EV:1.00

callout.para: The current exposure value change (+1.0EV after some frames)

section.para: If ISO ramping is not activated then the ISO is not shown on the display.
While &BRAMPUINO1X; is running and taking frames some settings can be changed. The buttons have the following meaning:

listitem.para: Stop shooting. This takes a while till the menu appears.
ISO Ramp up by one step.
Decrement the Exposure Value Change by 0.1.
Increment the Exposure Value Change by 0.1.
Enter the menu while &BRAMPUINO1X; is still shooting. All parameters can be changed but not all show an effect. Select &MENU_start; to return to the running screen.

section.para: When shooting is finished &BRAMPUINO1X; switches the RGB LCD color to green.

chapter.title: Running &BRAMPUINO1X;
chapter.para:
In
the following sections we give a deeper insight into the interval and ramping time computation.

section.title: The Exposure-Interval Cycle
section.para:
In the normal exposure-interval cycle is shown: the overall bulb-time is the sum of the exposure offset time and the exposure time. Each exposure starts when the interval time is over.
Normal Exposure-Interval Cycle

In the adapted exposure-interval cycle is shown: &BRAMPUINO1X; uses the minimal interval time, if the interval time minus the bulb time is less than the configured minimal interval time.
Adapted Exposure-Interval Cycle

If &BRAMPUINO1X; ramps down, eg during a sunrise, and the interval time is less than the start exposure time then the interval time from exposure start to the next exposure start gets shorter and shorter, because the exposure time gets shorter and the minimal interval will be used, till the exposure time is less than the interval.
This is an implicit interval ramping.

section.title: Ramping with &MENU_expfps;
section.para:
In we show how &BRAMPUINO1X; ramps the exposure value up (exposure time and ISO) with a lead in of l frames.
The exposure time change is computed by the parameters set in &MENU_expfps; and &MENU_expev;.

First, there are l frames with the start exposure time specified in menu entry &MENU_exptime;.
Then the frame l+1 has still the start exposure time as if no lead in was set.
&BRAMPUINO1X; starts ramping now and frame l+fps+1 gets the full exposure change set in &MENU_expev;.
Ramping continues till the maximum exposure specified by &MENU_expmax; and &MENU_isomax; is reached.
When ramping reaches this maximum exposure &BRAMPUINO1X; continues to take frames with this maximum exposure till the maximum number of frames or the ramping time is reached.
Ramping with a Lead In

section.title: Ramping with &MENU_rampcalctime;
section.para:
In we have shown how the menu entry &MENU_expfps; can be used to define how fast the exposure will change from frame to frame.
Sometimes it is more convenient to define the exposure change not in terms of frames but duration. With the menu entry &MENU_rampcalctime; a time in minutes can be defined after which the exposure will have changed by the value defined in &MENU_expev;.
&BRAMPUINO1X; will compute and store the FPS value.

It depends on the interval time and the exposure value change.
If the interval time is less then the exposure value (see ) then is computed value might not be the expected value.

section.title: How to Stop Ramping
section.para:
Ramping can be stopped automatically and manually.
It is stopped automatically if the maximum exposure (time and ISO) or the ramping time (&MENU_rampfixedtime;) is reached.
And it is stopped manually if the exposure value change (&MENU_expev;) is set to 0.
In any case &BRAMPUINO1X; continues to take frames till the maximum number of frames are shot.

chapter.title: Uses of &BRAMPUINO1X;
chapter.para:
The &BRAMPUINO1X; can be used in different contexts if the parameters are set properly.
In any case the &BRAMPUINO1X; must be connected to the camera via an USB-cable.

example.para:
If you set the exposure time to 1000, the exposure fps to 150 and the exposure change value to 4.0 then the exposure will change by 4 exposure values and the 151-th frame
will have a 16000 milliseconds exposure time.
